This clinical trial, titled "Comparison of the Pressure Ulcer Prevention Effects of Two Mattresses With Different Support Surfaces Used in Bedridden Patients," aims to investigate the effectiveness of a massage mattress with a cube/block system in preventing pressure ulcers compared to a standard mattress with an orthopedic support surface in bedridden patients at low risk of pressure ulcers as determined by the Braden Scale. Both groups received initial assessments using the Braden Scale and were monitored for four weeks with daily pressure ulcer assessments using the Pressure Ulcer Observation Form. The size of the pressure sore area was measured in square centimeters using the Wound Measurement Ruler. The primary outcome measure was the number of patients without pressure ulcers at the end of the four-week follow-up period. The study utilized a parallel assignment design with triple masking. Eligible participants included bedridden individuals with a low risk rating on the Braden Scale, voluntary informed consent or consent from a legal guardian for unconscious or confused patients, absence of pressure sores upon admission, and a BMI less than or equal to 30. The study excluded patients who's bed was changed in less than ten days after inclusion, patients who were referred, and patients who were discharged during the study.

Note: This summary does not explain how the summary was created, but rather presents a concise and accurate synopsis of the clinical trial information provided.

The clinical trial titled "The Effect of Virtual Reality on Preoperative Anxiety Before Abdominal Surgery" aims to investigate the impact of virtual reality on managing preoperative anxiety in patients undergoing abdominal surgery. The study will utilize a randomized design with an experimental group that will watch a virtual reality video using mobile virtual glasses, a placebo group that will view the same video without virtual reality, and a control group that will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures will include the preoperative anxiety level assessed through a smart bracelet and the Visual Anxiety Scale. The study intends to answer two questions: the frequency of anxiety before abdominal surgery and the effectiveness of virtual reality on anxiety management before abdominal surgery. 

Variables such as preoperative anxiety scale/level, smart wristband with stress level measurement feature, and a patient information form will be used to collect data. The study has a sample size of 96, with 32 patients in each group. The data will be analyzed using parametric or non-parametric tests, depending on normality, with descriptive analysis through mean, standard deviation, and percentage distribution methods. The study has a primary focus on supportive care and does not mask the intervention. The trial excludes individuals not willing to participate, those undergoing surgery other than abdominal, and those unable to communicate in Turkish.

<|assistant|>
Title: Clinical Performance and Safety of Suture-TOOL for Abdominal Wound Closure

Objective: This study aims to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and safety of the Suture-TOOL device for abdominal wound closure during elective open abdominal surgery in individuals who meet the eligibility criteria.

Design: This is a single-arm prospective interventional study with no masking (open-label) to assess the Suture-TOOL device's effectiveness in closing abdominal wounds.

Participants: Men and women aged 18 years or older who are scheduled for elective open abdominal surgery for benign or malignant colorectal disease with a midline incision of at least 12 cm. Individuals with specific exclusion criteria, such as previous abdominal midline surgery, significant physical findings, or diseases that may interfere with the study, are not eligible for participation.

Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with a suture length-to-wound length (SL/WL) ratio of 4 or more during laparotomy closure. Secondary outcome measures include the stitch count, number of sutures used, closure times, surgeons' comfort, and satisfaction with final closure results.

Time Frame: Primary and secondary outcome measures are measured during the laparotomy closure.

Summary: This clinical study evaluates the Suture-TOOL device's effectiveness and safety in abdominal wound closure during elective open abdominal surgery. The study assesses various outcome measurements, such as the length-to-width ratio of sutures used, comfort, satisfaction, and closure times. The study is limited to individuals who meet the eligibility criteria, excluding those with specific pre-existing conditions or abdominal surgeries.

The clinical trial, titled "Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma," aims to examine immune changes in patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma and benign salivary gland tumors, as well as healthy controls with functional diseases of the nose or ear. The study will evaluate the immune matrix, comprising immune cell markers and tumor cell markers, using liquid immune profile-based signatures and tumor associated lymphocytes (TALs). Its primary outcome measure involves assessing changes in the immune matrix and immunophenotyping from baseline to the end of the study period, which is up to five years. Additionally, the study will analyze cytokines, metabolites, and microbiomes in participants' blood, tumor, and stool, respectively. The trial includes individuals aged 18 and above, with sufficient cognitive capacity and suitable for participation, and excludes those with distant metastases, simultaneous second cancers, drug or medication abuse, or inability to understand the study's purposes.

<|assistant|>
The study titled "Determination of Compliance to Mediterranean Diet, Impacts on Walking and Quality of Life in Multiple Sclerosis" aims to investigate the adherence to the Mediterranean diet, the use of various nutritional supplements, physical activity habits, walking-related issues, and quality of life in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS). Participants between the ages of 18 and 65 who have been diagnosed with MS, voluntarily agreed to join the study, and do not have exclusion criteria will be eligible. The study measures compliance with the Mediterranean diet using the 14-item Mediterranean Diet Adaptation Scale (PREDIMED), the quality of life of individuals using the Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale, the impact of walking using the 12-item MS Gait Scale, and the disability status using the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS). The study will last for one year, and the outcomes will be measured at specific time points. Keywords related to the study include multiple sclerosis, Mediterranean diet, quality of life, and walking.

Disclaimer: I only summarized the given text and did not explain how I summarized it.

The SIIT-CD study is a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools in patients with moderate to low responsive Crohn's disease. The study includes individuals aged 18-75 with active disease, and excludes those with extensive bowel resection, significant liver, kidney, or cardiovascular disorders. Participants are randomized to either the SIIT group, receiving intensive ustekinumab induction therapy, or the non-intensive induction therapy group. The primary outcome measure is the difference in clinical response rate at week 24 between the intensive and standard induction regimens. The study has a parallel assignment and is unblinded (open label).

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "The Preference of a Culturally and Linguistic Diverse (CALD) Population for Second Line OAB Therapy: a Discrete Choice Experiment," aims to compare the preferences of adults with overactive bladder (OAB) from a diverse population for second-line therapy, specifically between botox and sacral neuromodulation (SNM). Participants will fill in a questionnaire with fictitious therapy options that have different botox and SNM characteristics to determine their preferences. The primary outcome measure is a discrete choice questionnaire, completed in one hour. This study excludes patients with prior SNM or botox treatment.

The clinical trial titled "Fractionated Stereotactic Ablative Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) With FOcal Dose Escalation on Dominant Lesion in Localized Prostate Cancer" studies the efficacy of SBRT with a focal dose boost on the dominant lesion (DIL) in individuals with intermediate or high-risk localized prostate cancer. The intervention consists of SBRT to the entire prostate (including seminal vesicles) at a dose of 36.25 Gy in 5 fractions, followed by a DIL boost of up to 50 Gy in 5 sessions with additional urethra and bladder trigone sparing constraints. The primary outcome measure is biochemical progression-free survival defined as Phoenix criteria, while secondary outcomes include adverse events, late and acute toxicities, and quality of life assessments using EPIC-26 and CTCAE scales. The study is a single-group assignment, and participants must have an intermediate or high-risk diagnosis, confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate, and T2-T3a clinical stage with visible DIL on mpMRI. Exclusion criteria include previous surgery or symptomatic urethral stenosis. The study is designed to measure local control, biochemical progression-free survival, adverse events, late and acute toxicities, and quality of life.

The study, titled "Serious Games as Emerging E-health Interventions for Young People With neurological or Respiratory Disorders (SMILER) - Project@Cnr," aims to investigate the use of serious games (SG) as a supportive tool for asthma treatment in children aged 12 to 17 with controlled asthma. Group 1 will play a running-themed SG, which tracks the child's movements and adapts the game's dynamics based on their specific motor skills and heart rate. Group 2 will follow the standard treatment plan without SG. The study's primary outcome is measured using the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita) at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA). Pregnant women, individuals with obesity, major malformations of the respiratory system, active smoking, respiratory infections or immunological, metabolic, cardiac, or neurological diseases are excluded.

This clinical trial, titled "Multidisciplinary Approach for High Risk Patients Leading to Early Diagnosis of Canadians in Heart Failure," is designed to improve the screening of heart failure and identify patients at risk earlier. It is a randomized, un-blinded study comparing usual care to an intervention group receiving early heart failure testing. The study seeks to determine if early screening and treatment can prevent further decline in high-risk patients. Participants, aged 40 or older with at least two risk factors for heart failure, will be identified through primary care electronic health records and invited to participate. In the intervention group, participants will undergo diagnostic tests including NT-proBNP, AI echocardiography, and electrocardiography if their NT-proBNP level is elevated. The primary outcome will be the number of participants diagnosed with heart failure, as well as outpatient HF visits, urgent HF visits, and HF hospitalizations. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of prescription for guideline-recommended HF therapies in patients diagnosed with HFrEF and HF events in HFrEF. The study will be conducted for six months, and both groups will undergo routine care, with the intervention group receiving additional diagnostic testing.

This clinical trial, titled "Lean Body Weight Scalar for the Anesthetic Induction Dose of Propofol," aims to evaluate the effectiveness of using lean body weight instead of total body weight or ideal body weight to calculate the dosage of propofol during anesthetic induction. The study will include patients with a BMI between 18 and 35 and will be observed during anesthesia for 2-6 hours. Propofol infusion will be started based on total body weight, and the relationship between dosage and body mass index will be evaluated. The study is an observational design and will not involve any non-routine procedures. The primary outcome measure is the ratio of propofol dose required for sufficient anesthesia based on both total and lean body weight. The key study terms include lean body weight and propofol intubation conditions.

This study is a prospective cohort design to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of letermovir for CMV prophylaxis in heart and lung transplant recipients. Participants will receive either letermovir or standard valganciclovir prophylaxis, and outcomes will be compared between the two groups. The study will measure CMV viral load, frequency of acute cellular rejection, and adverse events such as neutropenia and thrombocytopenia. The study will include adults over the age of 18 and exclude those with certain medical conditions or on certain medications. The study will last up to 365 days following the intervention. The primary outcome is the incidence of CMV viral load exceeding 1,000, CMV syndrome, or tissue invasive CMV disease during the prophylaxis period and 180 days after. The secondary outcomes include the frequency of acute cellular rejection, the proportion of subjects who develop neutropenia, severe thrombocytopenia, or unplanned discontinuation of MMF or azathioprine, and the incidence of incorrect renal dosing of letermovir. Keywords for the study include CMV and thoracic transplant.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial aims to develop and validate a scale, called the PHYSIOSCORE, to assess the complexity level and physiotherapy care required for hospitalized patients with heart and lung conditions. The study involves ten specialists in physical therapy who define four objectives for the scale: the use of variables in clinical practice, applicability to hospitalized adult patients, feasibility, and inter-examiner reliability. The committee reaches consensus on 106 items through the Delphi technique, divided into three domains: respiratory, imaging, and neuromuscular. A group of ten physical therapists assess two patients simultaneously, with a minimum interval of 15 minutes, to establish concordance and interrater reliability. The study includes 110 patients, with similar inclusion criteria as the previous phase, who are evaluated by the PHYSIOSCORE, EuroSCORE, SAPS 3, and ARISCAT scales three times during hospitalization or until discharge. The study also collects information about patients' characteristics at admission. The primary outcome measures include respiratory and neuromuscular variables assessed over three years. The study's main objectives are to validate the scale's feasibility and inter-examiner reliability and to demonstrate its ability to accurately measure the complexity level and physiotherapy care requirements for hospitalized patients.

The study aims to investigate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of a 3-month digital health coaching program for individuals with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma. Participants will receive weekly coaching calls and a Fitbit device to track their physical activity. The primary outcome is the retention rate of participants completing the coaching program, and the secondary outcome is measuring changes in self-efficacy using the Cancer Behavior Inventory-Brief Form (CBI-B). This study will provide insight into the symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being of this patient population using a combination of patient reported, wearable, and clinical data.

This is a randomized clinical trial investigating the efficacy of porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) in combination with a coronally advanced flap (CAF) for the treatment of localized gingival recessions. The study enrolls participants with RT1 recessions (3-5 mm in height) and at least 2 mm of keratinized tissue width, excluding smokers, pregnant or nursing women, individuals with diabetes or medications interfering with tissue repair, allergies to study components, or a plaque or gingival index greater than 20%. The study features a quadruple masking design, with participants randomly assigned to receive either CAF alone or CAF in conjunction with PADM. The primary outcome measure is recession reduction, assessed at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months, with secondary outcomes including evaluation of keratinized tissue thickness at the same time points.

This clinical trial investigates the impact of physical exercise conducted through virtual reality games during hemodialysis sessions on chronic renal patients' heart rate variability modulation. Group A will participate in virtual reality exercises, while Group B will engage in conventional exercise on a stationary bike. After 10 sessions, there will be a washout week, and participants will switch groups. Heart rate, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, blood pressure, and other measures will be assessed throughout. The study aims to compare changes in heart rate variability modulation between the two groups, determine the virtual environment's impact, and evaluate the relative efficacy of conventional and virtual exercise in improving heart rate variability modulation for chronic renal patients during hemodialysis. Keywords include hemodialysis, physical exercise, virtual reality, Renal Insufficiency, and heart rate variability.

The clinical trial, titled "Study of the Effectiveness of Central Line Placement Using an Ultraportable Ultrasound Device," compares the use of an ultraportable ultrasound device for central line placement to conventional ultrasound methods. The study includes adults scheduled for central line placement in the ICU or preoperatively, excluding pregnant women, suspected jugular thrombosis cases, and emergency procedures with no randomization option. The study's primary outcome measure is the procedure's length, defined as the time between starting the ultrasound scan after sterile protective device placement and fixing the catheter to the skin after confirming its correct position. Both experimental and comparison groups participate, with the experimental group using the ultraportable ultrasound device and the comparison group receiving conventional ultrasound guidance during central line placement. The study's design is randomized, parallel assignment, and single-blind masking only for the operator.

The clinical trial titled "Influence of Gut Microbiome in Gallstone Disease" aims to examine the gut microbiome profile of adults with newly diagnosed gallstone disease and its correlation with patient outcomes, such as complications and post-operative outcomes. The study will collect clinical and diagnostic data, anthropometry, and blood and imaging results from 75 participants at various timepoints. Stool samples will also be gathered, along with a food diary, at each timepoint for microbiome analysis. The study seeks to identify differences in microbiome composition between patients who experience complications, both pre and post-op, and those who do not, as a preliminary step toward determining interventions to reduce complication instances. Gallstone disease affects approximately 10-15% of people in the UK, resulting in over 65,000 cholecystectomies per year, with complications costing the National Health Service (NHS) more than £25 million annually. This trial aims to contribute to our understanding of gallstone disease and reduce the financial and symptomatic burdens on patients and the NHS.

The clinical trial, titled "Analyse Of Early Skın To Skın Contact's Impact Upon Maternal-Infant Bondıng And Perceptıon Of Traumatıc Bırth," aims to examine the effects of early skin-to-skin contact on maternal-infant attachment and perceptions of traumatic birth. The study enrolled 350 women who had normal deliveries at the Training and Research Hospital in Batman between December 2021 and May 2022. The participants were randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which received skin-to-skin contact, or the control group, which received standard midwifery practices. Maternal attachment was measured using a scale developed by Mary E. Muller in 1994 and adapted to Turkish by Kavlak and Şirin in 2009, and traumatic birth perception was evaluated using a scale developed by Yalnız et al. (2016). Both measures were taken shortly after birth and continued for a month after delivery through telephone interviews. The study was conducted as a randomized controlled experimental study to provide new information to the literature on early skin-to-skin contact's impact on maternal-infant bonding and traumatic birth perception.

This clinical trial investigates the efficacy of a sacral erector spinae plane block (ESPB) in managing post-operative pain for patients undergoing lumbar discectomy surgery. The study is a randomized, controlled, double-blind trial with both groups receiving standard general anesthesia. After the surgery, the ESPB group receives the block at the sacral level, whereas the control group does not receive any block. Both groups receive patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) and are monitored for pain scores and opioid consumption for 24 hours. Secondary outcomes include nausea-vomiting and patient satisfaction. The study aims to determine the impact of ESPB on post-operative pain management and potential side effects.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial aims to develop and validate a non-invasive multimodal ultrasound-based imaging biomarker for myofascial pain, a common contributor to chronic low back pain (cLBP). The study will use deep learning to integrate echogenicity, strain tensors, and ultrasound shear wave elastography measurements of latent and active trigger points, thoracolumbar fascia, and multifidus muscle deformation to create a predictive biomarker for myofascial pain. In the R61 Phase (years 1-3), the biomarker's sensitivity and specificity to classify myofascial components of pain and predict response to treatment will be tested. Eligible participants with cLBP and a myofascial pain component will be classified into one of four categories based on standardized clinical examinations. The study will also examine the presence of substantial myofascial pain. Healthy normals without chronic pain will not receive any interventions. The study includes participants with cLBP who have myofascial pain without trigger points, myofascial pain with latent trigger points, and myofascial pain with active trigger points. Keywords include ultrasound, trigger points, myofascial pain, thoracolumbar fascia, multifidus muscle, and neural understanding network.

The clinical trial entitled "Impact of Neuro-linguistic Programming on Schoolchildren's Performance" explores the potential benefits of NLP techniques on academic outcomes in schoolchildren aged 5-11 years in Lebanon. The trial involves a behavioral intervention utilizing a neuro-linguistic program developed by three specialists, consisting of four sessions for teachers and two for students totalling six sessions. The study measures the impact of NLP on school triggers, behavior, and academic performance using three tools: the "Identify School Triggers" questionnaire, the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire for parents, and the Vanderbilt Assessment Scale for teachers. The primary outcomes will be evaluated two months after the intervention. The trial follows a supportive care design, adopting triple masking, and has a sample size of 130 children from the same school, attending for at least a year.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial, "Effect of Using the ECOX Teaching Tool in the Emergency Department on OSCEs for Medical Students: Randomized Controlled Trial," compares the effectiveness of the ECOX tool in improving medical students' performance on service Emergency Care Orientated Clinical Examinations (ECOS) compared to standard learning during the training course. The study includes medical students aged 18 and over in emergency departments who participate in scheduled ECOS at the end of their internship. The control group uses their usual revision methods, while the interventional group uses the ECOX tool available in the emergency department to practice before taking their on-duty OSCEs. Primary outcomes measure student performance on end-of-course OSCEs, and secondary outcomes assess psychological status and student know-how during ECOS. The study runs for 10 weeks and measures STAI-Y scores and behavioral assessment scores during ECOS in each group.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial evaluates the effects of a web-based health care program on Pulmonary Hypertension (PH) patients' symptom management, social support, activity tolerance, and quality of life. The program aims to improve social support, self-care ability, active tolerance, symptom distress, anxiety, and depression in PH patients. The study includes patients with PH aged 20-90 years, who are diagnosed with Group1 or Group4 PH, have internet or mobile internet access, are aware of their diagnosis, are mentally stable, and do not have alcohol or drug addiction. Usual care remains the control group. The study employs a randomized, paralleled, double-blind, block-randomized design, and measures PH symptoms, social support, activity ability, and quality of life at six months using standardized tools such as PAHSS, MSPSS, 6MWD, and CAMPHOR. The trial aims to determine the effectiveness of the web-based health care program for PH patients.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "Effects of Long Term Ventilation Support on the Quality of Life of ALS Patients and Their Families", aims to compare the impact of using long term mechanical ventilation support (LTMV) on the overall quality of life of ALS patients and their families with those who do not choose LTMV. Primary outcomes are measured by the Quality of Life Scale at four time points, while secondary outcomes include health-related quality of life, caregiver burden, disease-specific quality of life, and health-related quality of life assessed by various scales. Participants include ALS patients with progression of the disease and their partners and children who can communicate in Norwegian. There is no mention of a comparison group for the patients who decline LTMV, implying that they will not be included in the study analysis. The study is not blinded or placebo-controlled, and its design is non-randomized with parallel assignment for both groups.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "Neurologic Deficits and Recovery in Chronic Subdural Hematoma," aims to assess neurological deterioration and recovery in patients with chronic or subacute subdural hematoma undergoing surgical evacuation. Participants will undergo ECoG monitoring, a diagnostic test, to detect spreading depolarization, which may indicate a higher risk of deterioration. The study will measure postoperative neurologic deterioration using the Markwalder grading scale and Glasgow coma scale. Secondary outcomes will include functional, cognitive, and quality of life assessments at 30, 90, and 180 days post-surgery. The study is a single-arm intervention, with no placebo or comparison group. Exclusion criteria include emergent surgery needs and severe baseline disability. The study is not accepting healthy volunteers.

<|assistant|>
The study, titled "Impact of Annual Versus Biannual Infusions of Ocrelizumab in Patients With Active MS, After 2 Years of Initial Treatment, on Freedom From Radiological Disease Activity at Two Years: a Multicenter Randomized Controlled Non-inferiority Trial," aims to compare the effectiveness of annual versus semi-annual infusions of ocrelizumab in patients with multiple sclerosis who have not experienced a relapse for at least 18 months and have active MS, RR or SP form. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of patients with no new or enlarged T2 lesions on MRI at 24 months, with MRI readings performed by an independent radiologist blinded to the treatment arm. Patients must be 18 years or older, have active disease, require follow-up MRI, and be eligible for social insurance. The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment and single masking design, and will last for 2 years. The intervention groups involve either annual or semi-annual infusions of ocrelizumab, otherwise known as Ocrevus. The study excludes patients with certain medical conditions, pregnant or breast-feeding women, and those already receiving systematically spaced doses of ocrelizumab.

<|assistant|>
The SPARCOL study is a clinical trial studying the effectiveness of the Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) procedure, which is a minimally invasive organ-sparing procedure for elderly, frail patients with early-stage colon cancer. The study is comparing CELS to standard colon resection surgery in terms of postoperative recovery, physical function, and quality of life using various assessments and questionnaires, including the Quality of Recovery 15, 30-second sit-to-stand test, six-minute walk test, EuroQol EQ-5D-5L, and EuroQol EQ-C30-CR20 questionnaire. The study is also measuring the incidence of intraoperative and postoperative complications, long-term oncological outcomes such as disease-free survival, overall survival, and recurrence, as well as hospital readmissions, 90-day mortality, and length of hospital stay using the Clavien-Dindo classification and the Comprehensive Complication Index. The study is recruiting patients aged 75 and older with a PS score of 1 or ASA score of 3, Macroscopically or pathologically confirmed colonic adenocarcinoma, clinical T1/T2 N0 M0, colonic tumor location not exceeding the ileal valve, and suitable for CELS resection according to Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) judgement. The study's primary outcome measure is the change in patient-reported postoperative recovery using the Quality of Recovery 15 assessment. The trial's protocol is outlined in detail, including the timelines for assessments and follow-up periods.

This clinical trial, titled "Effectiveness of Nebulised Hypertonic Saline to Decrease Respiratory Exacerbations in People With Neuromuscular Disease or Neurodisability: a Phase 2 Open Label Pilot Study," aims to investigate the effectiveness of nebulised 6% hypertonic saline in reducing respiratory exacerbations in individuals with neuromuscular diseases or neurodisabilities, specifically those who have experienced at least one exacerbation requiring antibiotic therapy within the past year. The study will enroll individuals aged 5 and above who are able to tolerate nebulised hypertonic saline. Participants will be randomized to receive either nebulised hypertonic saline or nebulised normal saline as a placebo comparator. The primary outcome is the number of antibiotic courses for respiratory infections over a 52-week period, while additional outcomes include lung function tests, airway inflammation, bacterial diversity, ease of airway clearance, health-related quality of life, treatment and family impacts, and health economics measurements. The study is a phase 2, open-label pilot study with no masking.

The clinical trial aims to develop a new metabolic imaging approach called activity magnetic resonance imaging (aMRI) for evaluating neurological diseases in patients with gliomas. The trial will compare the aMRI parameter k⁰⁎*V in tumor regions with normal-appearing brain regions using a standard metabolic imaging approach, ¹⁸FDG PET, as a reference. The primary objective is to determine if aMRI accurately distinguishes tumor regions from normal brain regions. The study will also compare the aMRI metabolic parameter in different normal-appearing brain sub-regions unaffected by tumor and evaluate its correlation with ¹⁸FDG PET data. Secondary objectives include distinguishing the contrast-enhancing ring region indicating the metabolically active tumor periphery from the less viable and/or necrotic tumor core and comparing how aMRI metabolic parameters change in disease lesions with different disease types, stages, and treatments. Patients with gliomas who require MRI and ¹⁸FDG-PET imaging are eligible to participate. The study involves receiving ¹⁸FDG and gadoterate meglumine IV and undergoing simultaneous MRI and PET scanning for 45-60 minutes. The outcome measures include mean values of k⁰⁎*V in tumor regions, tumor periphery and core regions, and different normal-appearing brain sub-regions, as well as correlation with ¹⁸FDG PET data.

This clinical trial compares the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) alone and ESWL in combination with tamsulosin therapy for treating upper ureteric stones in patients with a history of stone formation less than 6 months ago, stone size between 6 and 15 mm, and no urinary tract infection. Exclusion criteria include multiple stones, strictures, prior unsuccessful ESWL, or concomitant use of certain medications. The study's primary outcome measure is stone clearance, evaluated 4 weeks after treatment, with a primary purpose of treatment. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with single masking.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "Interventional Therapy of Tracheal Stenosis After Percutaneous Tracheotomy," aims to investigate the effectiveness of interventions for tracheal stenosis that develops after a percutaneous tracheotomy. The study includes participants with tracheal stenosis but excludes those who have undergone surgical tracheotomy or are pregnant or nursing. The study's primary outcome measure is the rate of successful decannulations after intervention up to hospital discharge, while secondary outcome measures include technical success, number of interventions required, type of intervention, clinical success, and additional treatment needed. The study will investigate these measures for a period of 12 months.

<|assistant|>
The DRIVE-Mind II study, taking place in Vietnam, is a community-based psychiatric intervention for people who inject drugs (PWID) with psychiatric disorders, such as depression, psychosis, or suicidal risk. Participants diagnosed with these conditions during the ANRS 12353/NIDA ROI DA 041978 DRIVE study will receive psychiatric consultations and medication for free on community-based organization (CBO) sites, as well as support from trained CBO members. The control group consists of PWID without psychiatric disorders who will undergo a one-year follow-up. Both groups will receive harm reduction services and linkage to care when needed. The study's primary outcomes include viral exposure, severity of substance use, and quality of life, with secondary outcomes including adherence to HIV treatment, factors related to access to care, methamphetamine-induced psychotic disorders, HIV and HCV incidence, and the cost of the community-based psychiatric intervention. The study aims to compare these outcomes between the two groups.

The study, titled "Medical Decision Making in Multiple System Atrophy: Developing Personalized Best Medical Care With Integrated Telemedicine and Mobile Palliative Care for Individuals With Multiple System Atrophy," is a 18-month, monocentric, randomized, rater-blinded study that aims to evaluate the impact of a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment plan with integrated mobile palliative care and telemedicine on the quality of life (QoL) of individuals diagnosed with multiple system atrophy (MSA) compared to a historical European MSA cohort. The study enrolls 46 individuals with MSA meeting all inclusion and none of the exclusion criteria. Participants undergo a baseline examination, which includes clinical, psychological, and neuro-rehabilitation assessments, and complete a falls protocol and blood pressure and bladder diaries prior to the visit. Based on the results, individualized treatment plans are prepared, which may include mobile palliative care interventions for wheelchair-bound individuals. The study includes two study arms: (1) the personalized best medical care arm, which includes a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment plan, and (2) the personalized best medical care plus telemedicine arm, which includes monthly telemedicine neurological, psychological, and rehabilitation consultations, as well as additional personalized best medical care options. The study measures changes in QoL, motor and non-motor symptoms, and healthcare preferences, and examines the need for medical, psychological, and neurorehabilitation interventions, healthcare professionals' and patients' satisfaction with individualized treatment plans and interventions, healthcare costs, and caregivers' QoL and burden. The study is funded by the "Europäische Region Kärnten/Koroška" and "Tiroler Zukunftsfonds" under the "EUROPEAN REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT FUND--INTERREG VI-A Austria--Slovenia" program.

The study titled "Use of a Water Soluble Conast-Based Protocol to Assist in the Management of Pediatric Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction" is a prospective observational study conducted at nine children's hospitals. Children with peritonitis, incarcerated or internal hernia, active intra-abdominal malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, recent abdominal operation, pneumatosis, pneumoperitoneum, or a contrast allergy were excluded. Children under one year of age were excluded due to a lower success rate of NOM in this age group.

The study was powered to detect a 15% difference in operative rate between the contrast and no contrast groups based on adult literature. The study design involved two arms, contrast group and no contrast group. The contrast group received an enteral contrast challenge with contrast dilution, volume, and agent not standardized due to hospital-specific formularies. The contrast agent used was either diatrizoate meglumine (1940 mOsm/kg) or ioversol (702 mOsm/kg). Patients received 30-200ml of contrast followed by X-rays at 8-12 hours and 24 hours after contrast administration.

The study collected data through the Research Electronic Data Capture (REDCap) software tool hosted at the University of Colorado. Data collected included patient demographics, medical and surgical history, clinical presentation, laboratory studies, imaging, management approach, complications specific to contrast administration, length of hospital stay, need for operation, indications for operation, and subsequent postoperative course and complications.

Statistical analyses included descriptive statistics, group differences tests, and logistic regression. The study aimed to compare the need for operation between the contrast and no contrast groups, adjusting for age, body mass index, volume of contrast, and previous laparotomies. A subset analysis was also performed among patients who received enteral contrast, comparing differences based on contrast agent and final osmolality. Comparisons were made between patients who were successfully managed nonoperatively and then between those patients who required abdominal operation, based on contrast status.

The primary outcome measure of the study was the number of patients who required an operation due to failure of nonoperative management. The study also measured total hospital length of stay in days among patients successfully managed nonoperatively and adverse events resulting from contrast administration. 

Terms used in the study include adhesive small bowel obstruction, enteral contrast challenge, contrast agent, contrast dilution, contrast volume, Pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction, pneumatosis, pneumoperitoneum, and contrast allergy. The clinical trial titled "The Coconut Technique - A New Method to Perform Safe Cholecystectomy for Acute Cholecystitis: Our Initial Experience" is a study aimed at testing a new procedure, called the "coconut technique," for treating acute cholecystitis during cholecystectomy. The study includes participants diagnosed with stage II acute cholecystitis in accordance with the Tokyo guidelines, who undergo surgery within three days of symptom onset. The procedure involves cutting a three to four centimeter section of the inflamed gallbladder wall, making an incision in a safe zone at the junction of the infundibulum and the body of the gallbladder, and searching for the separation between the outer layer and the inner layer. This process enables clear identification of the confluence between the cystic duct and the body of the gallbladder, which helps in determining if the procedure was safely completed using the current technique. After identifying the confluence, the cystic duct is clipped, allowing the gallbladder to be lifted and turned over, leaving the unidentified common bile duct untouched. The study's primary outcome measure is the success rate of this new technique during cholecystectomy, which is evaluated over a two-year period. Keywords related to the study include acute cholecystitis, cholecystectomy, and cystic duct.

Can you provide a summary of the study design and what they are trying to achieve in the Endocalyx for Heart Failure clinical trial? 


Brief summary:

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of Endocalyx, a dietary supplement containing glycosaminoglycans, on reducing sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure. The study also aims to explore whether Endocalyx improves physical limitations, patient-reported outcomes, microcirculation characteristics, tissue sodium content, office blood pressure, heart rate, cardiac output, and total peripheral resistance, as well as reduces total body water and body weight. The study will also assess the safety of Endocalyx in heart failure patients by comparing the incidence of adverse events between Endocalyx and placebo groups. The study will last for 8 weeks, and participants will be randomly assigned to either the Endocalyx or placebo group, both receiving a daily dose of 4 capsules. Blood, urine, and skin biopsy samples will be collected at different timepoints for analysis, including aldosterone and renin levels, 24-hour urine sodium and potassium excretion, lippolysaccharide-mediated cytokine secretion of monocytes, antihypertensive drug dosage or number prescribed, and diuretics (dosage or number prescribed). The study will include exploratory subgroup analyses to evaluate differential treatment effects of Endocalyx in male and female patients due to important gender differences in heart failure characteristics and the suggested working mechanism of Endocalyx.

Detailed summary:

The study, titled "Endocalyx for Heart Failure: A Proof of Concept, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study," aims to assess the effectiveness of Endocalyx, a dietary supplement containing glycosaminoglycans, in reducing sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure. The trial is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study involving participants aged 18-110 years, who meet the inclusion criteria including documentation or suspicion of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF and HFmrEF according to ESC guidelines). Participants will be randomly assigned to either the Endocalyx or placebo group and will receive a daily dose of 4 capsules, with Endocalyx group taking either 2 capsules twice daily or 4 capsules once daily. The trial will last for 8 weeks, with participants undergoing several assessments at different timepoints including physical examinations, blood tests, 24-hour urine collection, ultrasound, and skin biopsies.

The primary outcome measure will be the degree of volume overload as measured by the change in NT-proBNP from baseline to week 8 in Endocalyx-treated patients when compared with the placebo group. NT-proBNP levels will be measured at screening visit, week 0 (randomization visit), week 4 and week 8. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in 24-hour blood pressure, total body water, body weight, hemodynamic parameters, concentration changes of adrenomedullin, changes/differences in ratio of classical (CD14++/CD16-), non-classical (CD14+/CD16+) and intermediate (CD14++/CD16+) monocyte subsets, lipopolysaccharide-mediated cytokine secretion of monocytes, hospitalization rates due to heart failure, distance covered during 6-minute walking tests, and changes in self-reported Quality of Life. The safety of Endocalyx in heart failure patients will also be assessed by comparing the incidence of (serious) adverse events between the Endocalyx and placebo groups. The study will take place in the Hospital of Rijndammer, Department of Cardiology, University Medical Center Utrecht, and the trial protocol is in accordance with GCP. The study has received approval from the Medical Ethics Committee of Utrecht University, and all participants will sign an informed consent form prior to participating in the study. The study seeks to determine the safety and effectiveness of Endocalyx as a non-osmotic sodium storage (NOS) compound, which is used to treat sodium retention, in the context of chronic heart failure. Ultimately, the study aims to demonstrate the potential of Endocalyx to reduce excess salt in the body, which is a significant challenge

This clinical trial, titled "Physiological MRI for Precision Radiotherapy IDH-wildtype Glioblastoma," aims to generate proof-of-concept for using a physiological clinical target volume (CTV) for radiotherapy treatment planning in patients with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma. The conventional CTV expanded by 1.5cm into healthy tissue to account for microscale tumor invasion has side effects, as it includes healthy tissue that should not receive radiation. The study seeks to tackle this issue by visualizing microscale tumor invasion through advanced MRI techniques that assess oxygenation status and cell proliferation in addition to the conventional MRI used for radiotherapy planning. The proposed physiological CTV, containing more accurate microscale tumor invasion information, will be compared to the standard CTV in terms of volume and location in 10 patients diagnosed with glioblastoma. The treatment for all patients will follow the current standard, and both CTVs will be used for planning. The study will also examine pattern-of-failure analysis to determine the efficacy of the physiological CTV compared to the standard CTV. No personal benefit is expected for patients participating in the study, which involves an extended MRI scan time during their standard radiotherapy planning MRI. The study aims to demonstrate the feasibility of using a physiological CTV in radiotherapy treatment planning, paving the way for future clinical trials to validate its benefits.

The study will assess the accuracy of PsUS elbow exams in terms of sensitivity, specificity, negative and positive predictive value, using radiography or bedside nursemaid reduction as a comparison. The feasibility phase will evaluate the acceptability and feasibility of the PsUS study protocol for adequate image capture. Overall, this study aims to compare the diagnostic accuracy of PsUS in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures with radiography as a reference standard.

The SPARROW clinical trial compares standard versus prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis for patients with a high risk of contaminated bile during pancreatoduodenectomy, as previous studies have shown conflicting results about infectious complications. A total of 322 patients will be recruited, with approximately 161 in the intervention arm and 161 in the control arm.

Answer according to: Your task is to create a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the provided clinical trial document. The summary should capture the key aspects of the trial.

Input Text: Comparing Retreatment of 177Lu-DOTATATE PRRT Versus Everolimus in Patients With Metastatic Unresectable Midgut Neuroendocrine Tumors, NET RETREAT Trial

Study Overview
=================

Detailed Description
-----------------
PRIMARY OBJECTIVE: I. To evaluate the effect of lutetium Lu 177 dotatate (177Lu-DOTATATE) versus (vs.) everolimus on progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with metastatic/unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumor (NET) who have progressed following previous peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT). SECONDARY OBJECTIVES: I. To evaluate the toxicity and safety of 177Lu-DOTATATE and everolimus. II. To determine the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE vs. everolimus on overall response rate (ORR). III. To evaluate the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE vs. everolimus on overall survival (OS). IV. To evaluate post progression survival (PPS) and time to second objective disease progression (PFS2) for patients randomized to Arm 2 of the study and crossed over to Arm 1 at time of objective progression per Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) 1.1. V. To evaluate the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE vs. everolimus on patient quality of life (QoL). OUTLINE: Patients are randomized to 1 of 2 arms. ARM I: Patients receive 177Lu-DOTATATE intravenously (IV) every 8 weeks (Q8W). Treatment repeats for two cycles in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicities. Patients also undergo computed tomography (CT) scan and collection of blood samples while on study. ARM II: Patients receive everolimus orally (PO) on a daily basis (QD). Treatment continues in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicities. Patients whose cancer worsens may cross over to ARM I. Patients also undergo CT scan and collection of blood samples while on study.

Official Title
-----------------
NET RETREAT: A Phase II Study of 177 Lutetium-DOTATATE Retreatment vs. Everolimus in Metastatic/Unresectable Midgut NET

Conditions
-----------------
Metastatic Midgut Neuroendocrine Tumor, Metastatic Midgut Neuroendocrine Tumor G1, Metastatic Midgut Neuroendocrine Tumor G2, Unresectable Midgut Neuroendocrine Tumor

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Procedure: Biospecimen Collection
* Procedure: Computed Tomography
* Drug: Everolimus
* Drug: Lutetium Lu 177 Dotatate
* Other: Quality-of-Life Assessment
* Other: Questionnaire Administration

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of Mulligan techniques with manual traction and McKenzie extension exercises with manual traction in managing chronic unilateral radicular low back pain in individuals aged 28-50 with lumbar radiculopathy. Both techniques will be delivered for four weeks, with two sessions per week and single daily sessions. Visual Analogue Scale, Oswestry Disability Scale, and lumbar range of motion will be used to measure pain reduction and functional improvement at baseline and four weeks post-intervention. Both male and female patients will be recruited, excluding those with spinal surgery, corticosteroid use, osteoporosis, fractures, trauma, inflammatory disorders, acute disc bulge, and lumbar instability. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with double blinding, and statistical analysis will be performed using SPSS 29. The primary outcome measures will be numeric pain rating scale, Oswestry Disability Index, and lumbar range of motion. Keywords for this study include low back pain, manual therapy, pain, and mobilization.

The clinical trial, titled "A Phase 2, Multicenter, Long-Term, Open Label Extension Trial Evaluating Safety, Tolerability, and Efficacy of Subcutaneous Doses of TransCon CNP Administered Once Weekly in Children and Adolescents With Achondroplasia," aims to investigate the safety, tolerance, and effectiveness of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP, a drug used to treat achondroplasia, in children and adolescents over a period of ten years. Participants must have previously completed a clinical trial with TransCon CNP, be between the ages of 3 and 15, and have experienced achondroplasia. The study's primary outcome measure is safety and tolerability, with the secondary outcome measure being height Z-scores, which will be measured through the trial's completion. Annualized growth velocity will also be monitored as a secondary outcome measure. This trial is a long-term, open-label extension of previous TransCon CNP trials, and participants will receive weekly subcutaneous injections via syringe and needle. The trial is an open-label extension, meaning all participants will be aware they are receiving the intervention. The study does not involve healthy volunteers.

This observational study aims to investigate the relationship between illness perceptions, coping strategies, self-efficacy, depression, and anxiety and their mediating effects on the quality of life of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF) patients. Participants between the ages of 18 and 75 with a diagnosed case of PAF, based on a 12-lead ECG and cardiologist-led examination, are eligible. Participants with severe complications, malignant diseases, psychiatric disorders, or cognitive impairments are excluded. The study measures patients' quality of life using the Short Form Health Survey (SF-12) at baseline and up to 24 weeks. The findings will help to understand the factors that affect the quality of life of PAF patients and inform the development of interventions to improve their quality of life.

The study is titled "Local Excision for Organ Preservation in Early REctal Cancer With No Adjuvant Treatment (LORENA Trial)" and it aims to determine the success rate of transanal local excision as a treatment for early rectal cancer (cT1N0M0) without the need for further adjuvant treatments like Total Mesorectal Excision (TME). The study will enroll patients aged 18 and above who fit the inclusion criteria, which includes a tumor's inferior edge not more than 2cm above the anorectal ring. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients who do not require TME after a 36-month follow-up, while secondary outcome measures include postoperative complication rates, radicality of resection, histological poor outcome predictor rates, and radical rescue surgery specimen quality. The study is designed to collect demographic, clinical, and pathological data through online data entry, and the statistical analysis will be performed using the Stata 13.1 software. The study will recruit patients from multiple centers during March to September 2023, with follow-up occurring from November 2023 to December 2027. Patients undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy, with a clinical TNM staging other than T1N0M0, or a tumor's inferior edge farther than 2cm above the anorectal rim are excluded from the study. The keywords provided by the Centre Hospitalier Valida include "early rectal cancer," "Local excision," "Total Mesorectal Excision," and "Organ preservation." The study is designed according to the 2013 Fortaleza's update of the Helsinki Declaration and participant country laws.

The clinical trial, titled "Remimazolam vs Propofol as an Induction Agent for Morbid Obesity Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy," aims to compare the efficacy of remimazolam and propofol as anesthetic induction agents in obese individuals undergoing sleeve gastrectomy surgery. The study is randomized, with participants allocated to either remimazolam or propofol induction. The primary outcome measure is the rate of hypotension events during the anesthetic induction phase, while secondary outcomes include induction time, time to loss of consciousness (LOC), and the total amount of vasopressor administered. The study requires a total of 88 participants, with each group consisting of 44 subjects, considering a dropout rate of 10%. The study is not recruititing healthy volunteers and excludes individuals with severe adverse effects or hypersensitivity to benzodiazepines or its additives, acute alcoholic intoxication, coma, shock, or narrow-angle glaucoma. The intervention/treatment for the remimazolam group is remimazolam anesthesia induction, while the propofol group receives anesthetic induction with propofol. Statistical analysis will involve t-tests, the Mann-Whitney U test, or Fisher's exact test, depending on the scale and distribution of the outcome variable.

The study titled "Gut Imaging for Function and Transit in Cystic Fibrosis 3 Junior: an Evaluation of Triple Combination Therapy in Children Aged 6 to 11 Years" aims to measure gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function, and liver endpoints in children with CF aged 6 to 11 years using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Participants with at least one copy of the Phe508del gene mutation will undergo MRI scans before and six months to one year after starting the triple combination therapy (ETI) licensed for paediatric patients in this age group. A group of age and gender matched healthy volunteers with no history of gastrointestinal disease will also undergo one set of scans. The study will measure the delta small bowel water (ΔSBW) and small bowel water content as primary outcomes, and liver volume, liver elastography, lung ventilation as secondary outcomes at various timepoints during MRI scans. The pilot phase of the study will test the scan protocol in three CF children and three healthy volunteers, and if successful, the study will progress to the main phase with 12 additional CF children.

The clinical trial, titled "Efficacy and Safety of Methylprednisolone Versus Dexamethasone in Caudal Block for Children Undergoing Hypospadias Surgical Repair: A Bi-center Randomized Controlled Study," aims to compare the effectiveness and safety of caudal block using methylprednisolone and dexamethasone for pain management in pediatric patients undergoing hypospadias surgery. The study involves a randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center design, where patients receive either dexamethasone (0.1mg/kg) or methylprednisolone (0.5mg/kg) added to bupivacaine (0.25%) in the caudal block. The primary outcome measure is the duration of analgesia, and secondary outcomes include postoperative pain levels assessed using the FLACC score and side effects such as nausea, vomiting, respiratory depression, and hyperglycemia. The study includes male patients aged 1 to 6 years with ASA physical status I-II who are scheduled for hypospadias surgery. The trial has exclusion criteria such as a history of neurodevelopmental delay, diabetes, allergy to local anesthetics or steroids, coagulopathy, known congenital anomaly of the spine, and local infection.

The clinical trial, titled "Prevention of Oral Mucositis in Head and Neck Cancer," is a randomized study to examine the effectiveness of a medical device containing zinc gluconate compared to a solution of sodium bicarbonate in preventing oral mucositis in patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy. Eligible participants include individuals with oral, pharyngeal, or unknown primary tumors receiving radiotherapy for curative or adjuvant purposes, who are able to self-apply the product. Both interventions will be administered for 63 days, with the test group using a zinc gluconate spray three times a day and the control group using a sodium bicarbonate rinse five times a day. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of oral mucositis one week after radiotherapy, with secondary measures including time of onset and severity grading. The study is a single-blind randomized clinical trial (RCT) with a parallel assignment design.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of white noise, heart sounds, and music on newborn pain during heel lance, a common medical procedure. With a sample size of 84 premature or term infants, the study adopts a randomized controlled experimental design where infants are exposed to one of the three interventions (white noise, heart sounds, or mother's preferred music) for 10 minutes before, during, and 20 minutes after the procedure. The pain level of the infants is measured using the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS) before, during, and after the heel lance, and the duration of the procedure and crying time are also evaluated. The study's primary outcome is the NIAPAS score, with a scoring range of 0-18 and categories for mild, moderate, and severe pain. Secondary outcome measures include crying time, assessed through video recordings witnessed by two independent neonatal nurses who are uninvolved in the study. Keywords associated with the study include heel lance, heart sounds, music, neonatal, pain, and white noise.

The study aims to compare verbal scores of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who received hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) with those who did not through a retrospective analysis of previous assessments. The participants were children aged 2 to 17, diagnosed with ASD and receiving applied behavioral analysis at Oxford Recovery Center. The control group received only applied behavioral analysis, while the HBOT group underwent 40 sessions of HBOT at 2.0 atmospheres absolute (ATA) for 60 minutes each. The verbal scores were measured using the Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program or the Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills at six-month intervals. The study's primary outcome is the change in verbal scores at the six-month mark, with secondary outcomes being the prevalence of HBOT-related adverse events monitored during sessions. The Medical Dictionary for Regulatory Activities was used to categorize these events by their system organ class and preferred term.

The clinical trial investigates whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) can reduce the risk of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection (ALND). Those who have previously had ALND, bilateral ALND, or allergies to the dye used intraoperatively are excluded. The study is a prospective, randomized, controlled trial with a primary outcome measure of arm lymphedema assessment at two years, as well as drainage amount, seroma/lymphocele occurrence, patient-reported outcome measures, and subclinical lymphedema evaluation at two years. The study compares ILR in the experimental group to no intervention in the control group. Masking is double.

The study, titled "An Educational Campaign to Stimulate Adoption of a Whole-Food Plant-Based Diet Amongst Stanford Physicians: The PLANT Study (Providers Learning About Nutrition Together)," is a randomized, delayed intervention trial testing a six-week multimodal educational program for Stanford providers in any department who agree to participate. The study will utilise a pre- and post-study survey to assess dietary habits, mindset for adopting a whole-food plant-based diet, and measures of motivation and confidence to adopt and prescribe a whole-food plant-based diet to patients. The study's purpose is to measure changes in diet ID score, mindset about whole-food plant-based diets, and stage of change (motivation and confidence) over six weeks. The study "Rehabilitation Needs in Patients With Early Breast Cancer: Validation of a Questionnaire Patient Reported Outcome" aims to translate, adapt, and culturally validate the PRO (Patient Reported Outcome) questionnaire for breast cancer survivors to identify rehabilitation needs in early-stage patients. The study includes 80 participants in the transcultural adaptation phase and at least 280 participants in the validation phase. The PRO questionnaire consists of 17 items that cover areas such as survivorship concerns, symptom management, and family and genetic issues, rated on a scale of 0 to 3. The questionnaire will be administered twice, 15 days apart, to identify agreement through the Interclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC) model. The study will run for 6 months. Exclusion criteria include patients with cognitive or memory impairment. The study aims to evaluate quality of life and psychological distress. Behavioral intervention is the use of the PRO questionnaire. This study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This study, titled "A Postpartum Adaptation Study of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience Parenting Program," focuses on treating symptoms of postpartum depression, anxiety, and parenting stress in new parents. The intervention is a 12-session mentalizing-focused parenting group therapy program called Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE). The study will assess changes in postpartum anxiety, depression, parenting stress, parental reflective functioning, and parent-infant bonding using self-reported questionnaires. Secondary outcomes will measure changes in infant temperament. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of CARE and its therapeutic group processes. Participants eligible to enroll are postpartum parents receiving postpartum OB/GYN or mental health services at Montefiore Medical Center who are experiencing moderate to high levels of depression and/or anxiety symptoms in the postpartum period and have not previously participated in a Connecting and Reflecting Experience group. The study's primary timeline is from baseline (approximately 0-2 weeks pre-treatment) to post-treatment (after completing Session 12, approximately 15 weeks after baseline measurement). Additional measures include ratings of treatment acceptability and feasibility and a qualitative feedback survey. Secondary outcomes, such as infant temperament, will also be assessed using a parent-reported questionnaire. The study's primary focus is to treat symptoms of postpartum depression, anxiety, and parenting stress, and its proposed outcomes will provide insight into the effectiveness of CARE and its therapeutic group processes.

The clinical trial titled "Radial Versus Femoral Access For Thrombectomy in Patients With Acute Basilar Artery Occlusion" aims to compare two methods of endovascular recanalization in patients with basilar artery occlusion within 24 hours of onset. The experimental group will receive the procedure via radial approach, while the active comparator group will undergo recanalization via femoral approach. The primary outcome measure is favorable neurological function (mRS score ≤ 3) at 90 days post-operation, while the secondary outcome measure is procedure time. Eligibility criteria include basilar artery occlusion, NIHSS score ≥ 10, age ≥ 18 years, and written informed consent. The study is a randomized controlled trial with single masking. Other exclusion criteria include concurrent severe medical conditions and previous interventional or open surgery that may affect radial or femoral artery puncture or delivery of instruments.

The BUNDLE study aims to improve maternal health outcomes and reduce healthcare disparities among Black or African American pregnant individuals through the integration of community doulas into prenatal care. The study has three objectives: (1) to develop a prenatal care model that integrates medical providers and community doulas, (2) to compare the effectiveness of this model to standard prenatal care, and (3) to disseminate findings and promote policy changes. The study is a prospective mixed-methods study with a randomized controlled trial component. Eligible participants will be randomly assigned to either the BUNDLE intervention or standard prenatal care. The BUNDLE intervention includes attendance by a doula at two visits in the second and third trimesters, exchange of information between the doula and medical provider, communication between the doula and medical team, doula support during labor, and postpartum doula support for cardiovascular risk reduction. The primary outcome measure is healthcare engagement, which includes attendance at recommended prenatal visits, attendance at the postpartum visit, and receipt of recommended vaccinations during pregnancy. Secondary outcome measures include trust in the healthcare provider, reported discrimination, perceived stress, depression, cesarean birth, unplanned healthcare utilization, severe maternal morbidity, breastfeeding initiation, and a survey focused on medical mistrust in the context of racism and discrimination. The study aims to improve patient engagement, trust, and reduce healthcare disparities.

This clinical trial titled "Text Messaging to Improve Adherence to Repeat Colonoscopy in a Veterans Affairs (VA) Hospital: A Pilot Study" aims to enhance adherence to repeat colonoscopy appointments among eligible VA patients through the use of instructional and motivational text messages. Participants in the experimental arm will receive a series of messages starting two weeks before and on the day of the procedure, reminding them of the appointment and aiding in completing bowel preparation, while those in the control group will not receive any messages. The study will assess participant satisfaction with the Annie text intervention using a 7-item questionnaire and track the percentage of patients who attend scheduled appointments and have adequate bowel preparation. The trial's primary outcome measure is the National Annie Colonoscopy Survey Score, with higher scores representing greater satisfaction with the intervention. The study's secondary outcome measures involve monitoring appointment attendance and assessing bowel preparation levels through electronic health records. This is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label trial with a minimum age requirement of 45 years and a maximum age threshold of 85 years for participants. Eligibility is based on criteria that exclude those due for colorectal cancer screening or with personal histories of CRC, IBD, or hereditary colon cancer syndrome. The study follows the screening primary purpose.

The study titled "Hysteroscopy vs. Endouterine Aspiration in the Management of Trophoblastic Retention" is a randomized, multicenter trial with open-label intervention comparing the effectiveness of hysteroscopy and endouterine aspiration in managing trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage. Patients with intrauterine retention after early spontaneous miscarriage (<14 weeks of amenorrhea) who desire pregnancy are eligible for the study. Misoprostol antibiotic prophylaxis and anti-adhesion barrier gels are used in both groups, and pathological examination is performed on the resected retention product.

The primary endpoint is uterine vacuity at 6 weeks after surgery measured by endovaginal pelvic ultrasound performed by a blinded investigator. Secondary endpoints include complication rates, rate of second-line surgical management, synechiae, mean time to conception, and pregnancy rates at 6, 12, and 24 months after surgery assessed by phone. The study expects to recruit 220 patients (110 per arm), adjusting for strata of center, age, size of trophoblastic retention, and scheduled by random size block. The study aims to demonstrate the higher effectiveness of hysteroscopy versus aspiration in achieving uterine vacuity, with an alpha risk of 5% and a power of 90% for the primary endpoint. Adverse events and complications during and after surgery are also monitored. The findings may contribute to optimal surgical management recommendations for trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage.

This clinical trial, titled "On-line Crowdsourcing of Multi-Timescale Inference Strategies," aims to investigate inference strategies at different timescales. Participants, who are adult Prolific users with a high approval rating and English fluency, will be asked to complete three blocks of psychophysics tasks. In the short-term block, they will guess which of two jars filled with red and blue balls is currently in use. In the long-term block, they will predict which jar will be used on the next trial, while in the multi-timescale block, they must both determine the current jar and predict the next one. The study will collect binary behavioral decision responses over approximately 30 minutes through computer-provided choices. The study is classified as basic science and is conducted in an open-label setting, asmasking is not used. Participants must be based in the US and have a minimum score of 80% on a pre-test. The study aims to examine inference strategies at different timescales, specifically short-term, long-term, and multi-timescale.

The clinical trial, titled "Therapeutic Evaluation of Treatment With Sinomenine versus Glucocorticoid for Early Knee Osteoarthritis: A Prospective, Double-Blind, Randomized, Multicenter Clinical Trial," aims to compare the effectiveness of sinomenine and glucocorticoid for early knee osteoarthritis. Participants aged 40-70 with bilateral knee pain for at least 6 months and Kellgren and Lawrence grade 2 or 3 osteoarthritis are eligible, except for certain exclusion criteria. Both treatments involve one intra-articular injection every 4 months, and the study will measure changes in the WOMAC score, tibial cartilage volume, and mobility tests at 24 months after the first injection. The clinical trial, titled "A Biobehavioral Approach to Understand the Multilevel Determinants of Cardiovascular Health in Black Women," aims to examine the cardiovascular health of Black women aged 18-49 years through a combination of lab-based assessments and free-living monitoring using mobile and wearable devices. Eligible participants, who must self-identify as Black or African American and own a smartphone with internet access, will undergo a series of lab-based assessments including evaluations of heart rhythm/rate, blood pressure, large and cerebral blood vessel flow, blood flow measurements, brain blood flow, carbon dioxide concentration, breathing rate, and cerebral vasomotor reactivity. Venous blood samples will also be collected to identify biomarkers that affect blood pressure and blood flow. During a 10-day free-living monitoring period, participants will wear a wrist-worn activity tracker and a blood pressure monitor bracelet, as well as use a smartphone app to complete surveys six times a day about their behaviors, social/physical context, mood/stress, and experience of racial discrimination/microaggression. Additionally, saliva samples will be collected on three consecutive days during the monitoring period. The trial will measure macrovascular and arterial stiffness functions, cerebral blood flow, and physical activity levels over 10 days. Exclusion criteria include diagnosed cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic, and neurological disorders, functional limitations, health issues, current medication usage, and recent smoking habits.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of RCN3028, a potential non-hormonal therapy, in treating moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes) caused by breast cancer treatment. Tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors, commonly used to treat breast cancer, can cause hot flashes in up to 80% and 30% of patients, respectively. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT), an effective treatment for hot flashes, is not recommended for breast cancer survivors due to cancer recurrence risks. Risperidone, an antagonist of serotonin and dopamine receptors, has been suggested to reduce hot flashes due to its effects on dopaminergic and serotonergic antagonism. The study will enroll female breast cancer survivors who have completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy, are on a stable dose of tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors, and experience at least seven moderate to severe hot flashes a day or 50 a week. Participants will receive either RCN3028 at 0.8mg or a placebo for 12 weeks, with a 14-day placebo run-in period. The study's primary endpoints are changes in the frequency and severity of hot flashes, measured through a vasomotor symptom episode event log and Menopause Specific Quality of Life Questionnaire, respectively. Secondary endpoints include 50%, 75%, and 100% responder rates, time to onset of efficacy, subject and physician global assessment, and treatment-emergent adverse events. RCN3028, if shown effective and safe, would provide a non-hormonal option for breast cancer survivors experiencing hot flashes.

This retrospective study aims to investigate the association between higher doses of tranexamic acid and a lower incidence of post-operative delirium in patients undergoing cardiac surgery at Royal Perth Hospital between May 2018 and August 2022. Tranexamic acid, a drug that inhibits plasmin production and stabilizes the blood brain barrier, has shown promising results in reducing nervous system inflammation caused by surgery and cardiopulmonary bypass. As giving tranexamic acid is considered standard of care in cardiac surgery, this study will analyze routinely collected clinical data to explore potential dosing regimens that could further lessen delirium risk. Primary and secondary outcome measures will include the Richmond Agitation Sedation Score and 30-day mortality, respectively. Due to the retrospective nature of the study, no patient contact is required. The statistical methods will be determined once the data distribution is known. Further, a randomized controlled trial comparing different tranexamic acid dosing regimens may be considered after the results of this study are available.

The study aims to compare two methods for suturing an ileostomy during rectal anterior resection surgery when the specimen is extracted via a stoma. The study will evaluate the complication rate, stoma discoloration, erosion, tissue overgrowth (DET score), pain level, and quality of life using a validated questionnaire at 30 days after surgery. The study is randomized, parallel-controlled, and open-label, and includes adults with expected survival for at least 6 months and a low risk of systemic infection or immunosuppression. Keywords associated with the study include NOSES (NEOstomy Surgical Education and Standardisation), ileostomy, complications, and stoma suture.

The study, titled "Progression in Cognition and Associated Activities of Daily Living Impairment in Parkinson's Disease," aims to investigate cognitive decline and functional impairment in activities of daily living in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The trial involves a follow-up assessment to determine the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) or mild cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease (PD-MCI) based on personalized interviews and defined criteria. The study will compare baseline and follow-up assessments of instrumental activities of daily living function, using both the patients' self-impression and informant-rating primarily based on the motor, cognitive, and total score of the Pfeffer Activities of Daily Living scale. Global cognitive performance will also be evaluated using the Consortium to Establish a Registry for Alzheimer's Disease (CERAD-Plus) battery and the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA). In addition, the study will examine domain-specific cognitive change using the mean z-scores of tests assigned to one cognitive domain. Eligible participants for the trial are people with Parkinson's disease diagnosed according to the United Kingdom Brain Bank criteria and included in the Amyloid-Beta in cerebrospinal fluid as a risk factor for cognitive dysfunction in Parkinson's Disease (ABC-PD) study. Participation criteria include the ability to communicate and understand study requirements and provide written informed consent. In cases where the participant is unable to give consent due to cognitive impairment, a legal guardian's consent is required. The study aims to follow participants for 6-8 years.
