The clinical trial aims to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium in preventing myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. Participants aged 18-80 with ASA grades I-II are recruited for the randomized, parallel-group study. The initial dose of rocuronium for pre-injection is set at 0.04mg/kg based on previous literature and preliminary tests. The dose is adjusted according to myofibrillation levels in subsequent patients. The primary outcome measure is the appearance of myofibrillation, determined by a yes or no response within 45 seconds of succinylcholine injection. The study includes three age groups: 18-44, 45-59, and 60-80 years old. Rocuronium is advanced intravenously before succinylcholine injection in all groups. The study does not use placebo or blinding to mask treatment allocation.

The study, titled "Presence of Environmental Pollutants in Human Carotid Atherosclerotic Plaques and Their Relationship With the Plaque Phenotype and Clinical Outcomes," aims to investigate the presence of air pollutants and microplastics in carotid atherosclerotic plaques of patients with extracranial high-grade internal carotid artery stenosis undergoing carotid endarterectomy. The study will enroll 300 consecutive patients with asymptomatic carotid stenosis and analyze plaque specimens for volatile organic compounds, microplastics, and inflammatory and plaque stability markers. Patients will be categorized based on the presence and abundance of pollutants, and the incidence of a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality will be compared between polluted and non-polluted plaque groups, as well as between terciles of pollutants burden. Masking is not used in this open-label study.

This clinical trial, titled "Effects of Low-Intensity Blood Flow Restriction Training in Normoxia and Hypoxia Conditions," aims to explore the impact of different training interventions on muscle strength, thickness, catecholamine, and inflammatory responses in physically active adults. There are six participant groups, including low-intensity resistance training in normoxia, high-intensity resistance training in normoxia, low-intensity resistance training combined with blood flow restriction in normoxia, low-intensity resistance training in hypoxia, and low-intensity resistance training combined with blood flow restriction in hypoxia. The study measures primary outcomes such as maximum absolute and relative force output, one-repetition maximum, maximum number of repetitions, countermovement jump height and power output, catecholamine response, muscle stiffness, and muscle thickness. Secondary outcomes include perception of pain and effort, blood pressure, and countermovement jump perception. Allocation is randomized, with parallel assignment and single masking. The study plans to conduct four sets of 30/15/15/15 repetitions or 4 sets of 10 repetitions with varying loads, performed twice a week for six weeks. Blood flow restriction is incorporated at a lower-limb blood flow restriction of 80% total occlusion pressure. The target population includes adults aged 18-30, who are sea-level natives, regularly physically active, and have prior resistance training experience.

The study is a phase 2 basket trial evaluating the effectiveness of the drug disitamab vedotin in treating solid tumors that overexpress HER2. The trial includes four cohorts: patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), ovarian cancer, and endometrial cancer. 

To be eligible, participants in cohorts 1 and 3 must have previously received a platinum-based therapy and either progressed or received prior chemotherapy or anti-PD(L)1 therapy, respectively. Patients in cohorts 2 and 4 must have progressed during or after platinum-based therapy and received up to two or three lines of prior cytotoxic chemotherapy for advanced disease. 

The study's primary outcome is the confirmed objective response rate, as assessed by response evaluation criteria in solid tumors version 1.1 (RECIST v1.1), measured over approximately three years. Secondary outcomes include safety, disease control rate, duration of response and progression-free survival, overall survival, pharmacokinetics of disitamab vedotin, and the presence of antidrug antibodies. The study will follow participants for up to five years. 

Keywords provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida include HNSCC, NSCLC, ovarian cancer, and endometrial cancer.

The study, titled "Driving Rehabilitation and Innovation for Evaluating Risk in Post-Intensive Care Unit Survivors," aims to address the impact of ICU-acquired cognitive decline on older drivers. The study will recruit a cohort of older ICU survivors with cognitive impairments and delirium who are regular drivers to participate in neurocognitive assessments and in-vehicle sensor deployment for 6 months. The primary outcome measure is total driving time, and secondary outcome measures include depression, executive function, attention, working memory, processing speed, health-related quality of life, anxiety, employment, driving trips, and driving behaviors. The study's objectives are to determine protocol feasibility and acceptability, evaluate the relationship between neurocognitive assessments and driving behavior and safety, and conduct stakeholder advisory panels to develop actionable driving safety data and rehabilitation strategies for ICU survivors and their care partners. The study is designed to contribute to the NIA Strategic Plan's goal to ensure safe driving for older adults. Exclusion criteria include severe communication disorders, access restrictions to vehicles, and driving suspension or loss of license.

The study is investigating the feasibility and safety of initiating noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) at home in children with medical complexity, rather than in a hospital setting. Currently, NiPPV is initiated in the hospital through a one-night sleep study, which can be challenging for these fragile and medically complex children. The home NiPPV initiation model aims to empower patients and families in treating chronic respiratory failure, improve delivery of high-quality patient-centered care, and optimize NiPPV use. The study will randomly assign 40 children to either standard NiPPV initiation in the hospital or home initiation via remote telemonitoring. The primary outcome is the recruitment and retention rate, and secondary outcomes include adherence to NiPPV, quality of life, and barriers and preferences of the intervention. The study seeks to explore the potential benefits and large healthcare impacts of the proposed home initiation model before embarking on a larger-scale trial. Key differences in chronic respiratory failure and family caregiver involvement must be considered due to differences in medical complexity between adults and children. The standard care for NiPPV initiation is currently unclear in children, as evident by Canadian guidelines. This study aims to fill this knowledge gap.

Generate according to: A Study to Compare Various Root Canal Cleaning Devices Based on Cavitation,Ultrasonic and Conventional Methods.

Study Design: A prospective, 3-arm randomized, non-blinded, single-center pivotal clinical investigation, performed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device with 2 comparator arms.

Primary objective: To test the effectiveness of the Endoclean device for root canal debridement up to 12-month follow-up.

Secondary objective: To test the extended effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device up to a 24-month follow-up.

Inclusion criteria: Patients aged between 18-75 years with ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification 1 and 2. Patients presenting with symptomatic and/or asymptomatic apical periodontitis and radiographic evidence of apical periodontitis in anterior or posterior teeth larger than 1.5 mm in diameter. Mature tooth with closed apices. Tooth that has never been treated with root canal therapy.

Exclusion criteria: Patients with pre-existing health or oral conditions that placed them at risk during the trial. Patients with generalized untreated periodontal disease. Patients with a history of analgesic intake within the past 3 days or antibiotics in the last 1 month. Uncooperative patients. Teeth with immature apices, root resorption, or requiring extensive prosthetic rehabilitation. Teeth that cannot be made functional nor restored or difficult to access teeth with no importance (wisdom teeth). Teeth with insufficient periodontal support. Teeth with poor prognosis, for example due to deep root caries, large root resorption or open apex cases. Fractured teeth. Local anatomical factors such as an inaccessible root end. Presence of fractured instrument in the root canal. Pregnant women. Patients unable to understand the study procedure.

Number of participants: Total number of participants = 109 subjects. Arm 1: 40 subjects. Arm 2: 40 subjects. Arm 3: 29 subjects.

Test device: Endoclean (Lumendo AG): hydraulic cavitation cleaning device. Control device 1: Passive ultrasonic irrigation (PUI). Control device 2: Rotary files with standard NaOCl irrigation.

Study duration: 2-3 years. The results of the Endoclean group shall be compared to data gathered from the comparator device groups and results shall be presented in the clinical investigation report.

Official title: A Comparative Evaluation of Effectiveness in Root Canal Debridement using Inertial Cavitation Device vs Passive Ultrasonic Irrigation and Conventional Preparation: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial.

Conditions: Apical Periodontitis.

The study aims to use the somatostatin-based tracer 64Cu-DOTATATE for macrophage imaging in cardiac sarcoidosis, comparing it to standard 18F-FDG PET/CT for diagnosis and monitoring treatment response in individuals with neuroendocrine tumors (negative control). The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in patients with cardiac sarcoidosis versus the control group without a history of inflammatory heart disease. Secondary outcomes include the rates of adverse outcomes in cardiac sarcoidosis patients and the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart in patients with acute lymphocytic myocarditis.

The study "Impact of Hypofractionated Radiotherapy Strategy After Surgery of Skin Carcinomas in Older Patients" aims to compare the efficacy of two modalities of radiotherapy in older adults (70 years and above) with non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) who have undergone surgery for high-risk tumors. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: surgery alone (arm A), surgery followed by moderate hypofractionation radiotherapy (arm B), or surgery followed by extreme hypofractionation radiotherapy (arm C). The study will assess the efficacy, acute and late toxicity, cosmetic results, HRQoL, treatment burden, and impact on regional recurrence, progression-free survival, and overall survival at 3-year follow-up. Eligibility criteria include age 70 years or over, performance status OMS 0-3, high-risk tumor features, and no prior RT or contraindications to surgery and RT. This prospective phase III trial aims to gather data on geriatric evaluation, HRQoL, and fractionation in older adults with NMSC and address unanswered questions regarding the utility of radiotherapy and its fractions in this population. The primary outcome measure is HRQoL assessed by the cancer-specific European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Core 30 (EORTC QLQ-C30) and QLQ-ELD14 module, as well as treatment burden, at 3-year follow-up.

This clinical trial, titled "Efficacy of Losartan in the Prevention of Paclitaxel-induced Peripheral Neuropathy in Breast Cancer Patients," aims to investigate whether the medication losartan can prevent paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy in women with early-stage breast cancer undergoing adjuvant or neoadjuvant paclitaxel chemotherapy. The study includes female participants aged 18 and above who have biopsy-confirmed breast cancer and are scheduled to receive paclitaxel at a dose of 80 mg/m2. Participants in the experimental group will receive standard-of-care management for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting as well as losartan 100mg, while the control group will only receive standard-of-care management for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. The study will monitor the incidence and grade of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy using the NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events after 12 weeks. The study will also assess patient quality of life using the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy/Gynecologic Oncology Group - Neurotoxicity (FACT/GOG-NTX) questionnaire and measure levels of nerve growth factor (NGF) in serum after 12 weeks. The trial is randomized, and both the allocation and masking are single. The study does not accept healthy volunteers, excludes individuals with certain comorbidities or medications, and is only open to female participants. The trial’s primary outcome measures are the development and grade of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy, and secondary outcome measures include patient quality of life and levels of nerve growth factor in serum. The study's keywords include paclitaxel, breast cancer, and peripheral neuropathy, provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This clinical trial investigates the effects of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester (GBKE) tablets on individuals with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment, commonly known as dementia. The trial enrolls 370 patients aged 65 and above with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment, randomly allocating them to either the experimental group (GBKE tablets combined with conventional hypoglycemic treatment) or the control group (conventional hypoglyceamic treatment alone). Measurements include cognitive function testing, memory function assessment, assessment of daily living ability, perform functional evaluation, and attention assessment. The trial lasts for six months, with the primary outcome measure being cognitive function testing using the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive section. Other measures, including the Auditory Word Learning Test (AVLT-H), Functional Activity Questionnaire (FAQ), Shape Connection Test A and B (STT-A&B) and Symbolic Digital Form Test (SDMT), are secondary outcome measures. Eligible participants include individuals with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment, aged 65 and above, who are able to cooperate with cognitive function testing and have no previous history of certain medical conditions. Exclusion criteria include type 1 diabetes, acute cerebral infarction or myocardial infarction within 3 months, severe liver and kidney dysfunction, malignant tumors, thyroid dysfunction, brain injury or cerebral hemorrhage within 3 months, folic acid and/or vitamin B12 deficiency, thrombin inhibitors, defibrillators, antiplatelet drugs, blood activating and stasis resolving agents, ginkgo biloba leaf preparations, and other trial medications. The study is randomized, quadruple-masked (participants, care providers, researchers, and data analysts), and parallel-assigned. The intervention model is paralleled assignment, indicating that subjects in each group receive a specific treatment simultaneously.

The clinical trial aims to investigate the diagnostic effectiveness of 89Zr-labeled panitumumab, a monoclonal antibody, in combination with positron emission tomography (PET) and computed tomography (CT) imaging for detecting indeterminate metastatic lesions in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). The study's primary objectives are to determine the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab-PET/CT for identifying metastatic lesions compared to standard imaging modalities, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), CT, and 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-PET/CT. Secondary objectives include comparing the rates of intervention (such as biopsy or other invasive procedures) between subjects with and without indeterminate metastatic lesions as identified by standard imaging versus the rates in those identified with 89Zr-panitumumab-PET/CT. The study is single-group and open-label, and patients receive panitumumab and 89Zr-panitumumab IV, followed by PET/CT imaging. The study will run for up to 7 years, with primary outcomes assessed by the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab-PET/CT compared to standard imaging modalities. Secondary outcomes compare sensitivity and specificity of all modalities, as well as rates of intervention.

The study is called the Net Transition Initiative and is focused on comparing the efficacy of two next-generation mosquito nets, Veeralin and Interceptor G2, to a control net in preventing malaria in Cote d'Ivoire. The trial is a three-arm superiority, single blinded, cluster-randomised study involving 33 villages in the department of Tiebissou, with village as the unit of randomisation. The study population includes adults and children aged 6 months to 10 years. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of malaria cases in children aged 6 months to 10 years over a one-year follow-up period, as determined by malaria rapid diagnostic test HRP2/pLDH [pf/pan]. Secondary outcome measures include malaria infection prevalence, vector density, sporozoite rate in Anopheles, and entomological inoculation rate. The study aims to detect a 35% relative reduction in malaria cases per child per year in the intervention groups, as compared to the control group. The study design involves randomisation at the village level, distribution of nets to households following national guidelines, recruitment of 50 children per cluster for a one-year cohort study, prevalence and entomological surveys, and insecticide resistance monitoring using adapted CDC bottle assays. The study seeks to determine the effectiveness of the next-generation nets in controlling malaria in areas with intense indoor malaria transmission and extreme resistance to pyrethroids in the major malaria vectors Anopheles gambiae s.s. And An. coluzzii. Keywords associated with the study include Anopheles density, Entomological inoculation rate, Malaria case incidence, and Malaria infection prevalence.

This study, titled "Improving Attendance in Community Wise," aims to enhance the effectiveness of Community Wise, a behavioral intervention designed to reduce alcohol and substance misuse in individuals with a history of substance use disorder (SUD) and incarceration in marginalized communities. The original Community Wise intervention, developed in partnership with the Critical Consciousness Collaborative Board, was shown to have a significant effect on reducing ASM frequency through the use of the multiphase optimization strategy (MOST) and community-based participatory research (CBPR) principles. However, attendance across the intervention sessions was found to be low. Thus, this study intends to identify strategies that improve attendance and reduce ASM, which will be achieved through a full factorial experiment with 144 participants. The strategies examined will include recruiting participants under supervision (those on parole, drug court, probation, or methadone maintenance), incentivizing intervention attendance, and delivering the intervention in an open group format. The study will also expand eligibility criteria to include women and individuals living in marginalized communities who have not been previously incarcerated. The primary outcome of the study is the number of intervention sessions attended, and data will be collected at baseline and three months post-baseline. By improving the attendance rate and retention in the intervention, this study will enhance the potency of the Community Wise intervention, which addresses concepts relevant to all people with SUD living in marginalized communities.

The study measures the effects of CST on apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and daily living activities using standardized tests at pre-test, intermediate test, and post-test. This study contributes to practice by providing further evidence for the standardization and generalization of CST for individuals with Alzheimer's disease and highlights the need for more clinical studies on CST applied by nurses. The study is conducted on individuals aged 60 years or older, with mild Alzheimer's disease, a Standardized Mini-Mental Test score in the range of 18-23, and the ability to speak and understand Turkish. The study is double-masked and the data will be analyzed using the SPSS statistical software.

The study, titled "Dalfampridine Combined With Physical Therapy for Mobility Impairment in People With Multiple Sclerosis," aims to test the hypothesis that combining dalfampridine, a medication that improves nerve conduction for people with multiple sclerosis (MS), and physical therapy, the leading non-pharmacological intervention for walking-related impairment in MS, will produce superior gains in mobility through augmented neuroplasticity. The study will enroll 48 participants with MS-related mobility deficits and EDSS ≤6.5 and will have four arms: dalfampridine only, physical therapy only, dalfampridine plus physical therapy, and physical therapy without dalfampridine. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the Timed 25-Foot Walk (T25FW), which is a test that measures the time it takes to walk 25 feet as quickly as possible. The study will also explore the comparative effectiveness of each intervention and evaluate functional connectivity before and after each intervention. The findings from this study will inform the design of further research examining longer-term outcomes and disease progression trajectories associated with the interventions. Key inclusion criteria include a confirmed diagnosis of MS, EDSS 6.5 or less, and the ability to stand unsupported for at least 10 seconds. Key exclusion criteria include co-existing neurological disorders or orthopedic conditions affecting mobility and participation in another clinical trial. The study is a parallel-assignment, randomized, controlled trial with single masking. The investigators will assess the change in T25FW at weeks 0-6 and 8-14 for each phase of the treatment: dalfampridine only (run-in) and physical therapy with or without dalfampridine. Exploratory aim 4 will examine specific clinical and personal factors associated with treatment responsiveness.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between cerebral perfusion and blood pressure changes during general anesthesia in patients with or without cardiovascular risk factors. It will measure non-invasively and simultaneously cerebral blood flow by transcranial Doppler, cerebral oxygenation by near-infrared spectroscopy, and brain function parameters by electroencephalogram. The study will enroll adult patients undergoing scheduled surgery at Lariboisière Hospital under general anesthesia. Blood pressure will be adjusted within recommended safety standards based on cardiovascular comorbidities, and measurements will be obtained continuously during monitoring. The study will primarily assess the relationship between percent changes in mean velocity (Doppler) and percent changes in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) during mean arterial pressure (MAP) changes. Secondarily, the study will evaluate the correlation between Vm and EEG markers such as alpha band power, time spent in burst-suppression, and delta-to-alpha ratio. The study aims to identify a significant linear relationship between Vm and SEF95 changes to determine if cerebral autoregulation is impaired, with a sample size of 100 patients required to reject the null hypothesis with 85% power and a type I error rate of 0.05. The study will not prolong anesthesia duration, and monitoring does not impact the prescribing physician's decision due to the study's stage.

The study, titled "Randomised Controlled Clinical Trial to Evaluate STERN FIX Device as a Sternal Stabilization System in Patients After Sternotomy," is designed to compare the efficacy of a sternal stabilization system, STERN FIX, in combination with wires to closing median sternotomy, to standard wires for closing median sternotomy. The primary outcome measure is sternal stability assessed using the sternal instability scale (SIS) at one month after surgery. The study will also evaluate safety measures, including adverse events, device deficiencies, reinterventions, sternal wound infections, and dehiscence, as well as secondary outcomes such as chest pain, blood loss, upper limb functional index, quality of life, sternal halves union/malunion, sternal halves alignment, sternum integrity, and closure system integrity at various time points. The study is randomized and double-masked, with a sample size of participants meeting eligibility criteria, which includes patients undergoing median sternotomy who have at least one of several risk factors and are willing and capable of granting informed consent and complying with the protocol requirements. The study is not open to healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial focuses on evaluating the performance and safety of vaginal administration of tocopherol acetate (vitamin E) for 14 days in pre-peri and postmenopausal women. The study aims to measure the vaginal environment's acidity, dryness, and integrity and assess various aspects of the vaginal microbiota, such as vaginal discharge, Whiff test, and bacterioscopic smear. The study also includes molecular sequencing-based microbiological analysis of the vaginal microbiota by next-generation sequencing (NGS) method. The trial will monitor serious adverse device effects, serious adverse events, adverse device effects, and adverse events using CTCAE v6.0. The study commenced on January 1, 2020, and concludes on December 31, 2022, while the Data Collection phase runs from June 30, 2023, to July 31, 2023. Women aged 50 to 70, undergoing premeneopause, perimenopause, or postmenopause are eligible to participate, excluding individuals with specific medical conditions or allergies to the tested medical device. The study's key keywords are premeneopause, perimenopause, postmenopause, vaginal eubiosis, lactobacilli flora, and microbiota.

PV patients diagnosed between 2014 and 2022 from Sohag University Hospital will be included, and patients with secondary erythrocytosis from the same hospital will serve as controls. The primary outcome measures are the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in both groups.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of measuring Perfusion Index (PI) with Masimo Radical-7 device on emergency triage classification in adult patients presenting with dyspnea. The study includes patients who have PI values measured at the time of admission, as well as at the first and second hours of hospitalization. The study compares the PI and oxygen saturation measured by finger probes to determine which is more helpful in classifying emergency triage status. Patients with dyspnea due to other causes, such as trauma or known vascular diseases, and those with COVID-19 PCR positivity who cannot complete perfusion index measurement are excluded. The study measures the use of PI for triage status at the time of admission, the first hour, and the second hour after admission. The study is diagnostic, using a single-group assignment and open-label masking, and evaluates the relationship between PI and emergency triage classification in patients admitted to the emergency department with dyspnea. Keywords associated with the study include dyspnea, emergency, perfusion index, and triage.

The clinical trial, titled "SmartMom: Teaching by Texting to Promote Health Behaviours in Pregnancy," aims to compare the impact of a behavioral intervention delivered via text messaging (SmartMom) with a control text messaging intervention on various health outcomes during pregnancy. The study includes pregnant individuals at 15 weeks gestation or earlier with a singleton pregnancy, reading and understanding English at grade 8 level, and living in Canada (excluding British Columbia). Both intervention groups receive weekly texts, with the SmartMom group receiving messages containing evidence-based information to encourage healthy behaviors during pregnancy, while the control group receives general pregnancy information without decision-making prompts. The primary outcomes include rate of weight gain within a recommended range and attendance at prenatal care appointments in line with Canadian guidelines. Secondary outcomes include changes in health knowledge, depression, anxiety, fear of childbirth, use of tobacco, vaping, alcohol, or cannabis, planned vaginal birth after cesarean, and exclusive breastfeeding at hospital discharge. The study also aims to measure adverse pregnancy outcomes and the incremental costs of avoiding suboptimal weight gain and inadequate prenatal care in the intervention group compared to the control group. The study design involves randomization with a parallel assignment and open label masking. The trial's keywords include prenatal education, perinatal outcomes, text messaging, mobile health, mental health, and health behaviors.
